name: Tree of Savior (English Ver.)
description: Tree of Savior(abbreviated as TOS thereafter) is an MMORPG in which you embark on a journey to search for the goddesses in the world of chaos. Fairy-tale like colors accompanied with beautiful graphics in TOS will have you reminiscing about precious moments all throughout the game.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 (64-bit) Processor: Intel i3 Memory: 8 GB RAM Graphics: NVIDIA GeForce 200 Series or later DirectX: Version 9.0c Network: Broadband Internet connection Storage: 32 GB available space Additional Notes: Keyboard, Mouse
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7 (64-bit) or later Processor: Intel i5 or later Memory: 8 GB RAM Graphics: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 860 or later DirectX: Version 9.0c Network: Broadband Internet connection Storage: 32 GB available space Additional Notes: Joypad available

reviews.review_text: Strongly recommend this for veteran MMORPG players

Despite the poor optimization, ping/fps issues, pay2market/trade/shared storage (which actually can be bought via in game cash via tokens.. so this isn't THAT big of an issue), and end game grindfest... this game was actually enjoyable in a group... till the deplorable party bug happened that would freeze everyone except 1 person in place every time a quest cutscene happened.  This issue was reported by dozens of people, over the past month+ of time and yet the only responses from any sort of administration were poor english automated 'GM' messages saying they were 'looking into the issue and working on a fix', which everyone knows is a load of bull when you only use automated messages for such things.  Now as a person who gets completely bored of solo play quickly and thrives on co-op fun... a critical game breaking issue like this, that doesn't get resolved and only gets met with automated trash breaks the game and I simply can not reccomend this for anyone who dislikes solo or is looking to play this with a friend or friends.  That aside there are other issues as well but alot of the people here have already addressed that.

To be totally honest with you, this game should not be available to the public in it's current state. It is essentially still a BETA and I suspect that on 04/28/16, when it goes F2P, it will still be in a BETA stage. Needless to say, there is a LOT of problems and issues with this game. If you can think of an issue, it's here somewhere.  That said, despite all the problems, all the issues, all the frustrating bugs and more, this is still a really good MMO. I can't recommend this to people who never played nor enjoyed Ragnarok Online or similar games. But those who did, should definitely give this a try at the very least.  To the developer, IMC GAMES. Please take these reviews heavily into consideration. You have a gem in your hands. It just needs an aggresive polish.
Poorly optimized. Not ready for release.

I spent a very large amount of time on this game and I can say without a doubt, I do not recommend this to players. I listed pros and cons at the top with a brief explanation based on my own experience. Keep in mind I am a primarily pve player so my opinions on pvp are based on what I heard from friends and players in-game. I had 16 characters and 4 pets, 3 characters at rank 8, 7 at rank 7 and the other 6 at rank 5.  Pros:   Pretty neat and cute, typical anime-style mmorpg aesthetic. There a lot of panty-flashing swordsman and archer classes if that's your thing (personally it's a turnoff for me)   The art style of the npc portraits unique, with exaggerated proportions on most   Large variety of class builds with the unique class system (also a con)   Some classes have neat interactions with each other, such as ice railgun from Cryomancer's Ice Wall and Monk's Energy Blast. Or the skill of Dragoon 2 to double the physical attacks done to a monster through a debuff   A large majority of Cash Shop items (including premium tokens and costumes) are purchaseable from other players with in-game silver   Every 4 hours you accumulate 1 free tp (cash shop currency) to a max capacity of 5 free tp, so you can purchase cheap cash shop items (megaphones and revive crystals) each day   An ok amount of events to help the players, ex. leveling tomes, gem abrasives to improve gems to improve gear, sometimes tp   The first time you experience bosses can be exciting, especially world and field bosses which can take many players to kill depending on the level   It's not standard point and click gameplay. Blocking, walking out of AoEs, action-type gameplay  Cons:   This game is VERY POORLY OPTIMIZED. Even if you have a high end machine do not expect to play the game at 60+ fps all the time, IMC stated over a month ago an optimization patch was on the way but it still has not come yet   There are a large amount of bugs that go on for weeks, or even a month or two without fixing, such as game-breaking ones like friends list crashing game or questing in a party getting you stuck (this one was fixed)   Content updates are extremely sparse especially compared to the Korean version. We get their ui fixes before any content always   Your looks are based on your class choice costumes, weapon, sub-weapon/shield, hats, and hair. Finer things such as eye lenses, some hair dye and expensive hair styles are cash shop only   You need a Token \ premium status to access ACCOUNT and silver storage, get 0 cooldown on attribute training, gain one extra run for daily dungeons and one extra reroll for cubes (The main source of rare gear)   *Having a large variety of possible class builds means that there are a ton of terrible to lackluster builds out there   You start with 4 character slots, if you want to explore builds you need to keep buying character slots    Pets also take up a slot so you need even more slots if you're using a pet class   There is currently a gacha system in the game, as of this moment I would not consider it pay to win, however it could go that way whenever the contents of it switch every 2 weeks   Premium outfits used to be able to be directly bought out of the cash shop and now they are locked behind the medal store which requires you to exchange gacha items for medals   A ton of reused models, textures, recolored enemies, reused bosses but with more hp, from levels 1-280. Variety finally pops up at 280+ content   The difficulty in this game feels artificial. Instead of giving monsters new moves to use, all the recolored higher level monsters are just given a enormous hp boost or enough defense or magic defense to render attacks useless   *Pvp is largely unbalanced, only solo queue is possible so you cannot play with your friends on Team Battle League   Depending on which server and region you play, the population could be absolutely terrible  Good or Bad? You decide:   To a certain extent you can solo your way to rank 7 via questing, after that you either need to do daily missions for a long time or grind in a group. At rank 8 it is no longer an option for most classes   Guilds require a rank 7 class to create with a current maximum of 35 members in a guild at the moment, leading to a few powerful guilds and a lot of inconsequential ones   PvP is directly linked to PvE, your gear matters, and doing pvp won't get you better gear, only abrasives to improve gems for gear   The game never evolves from 'kill stuff, ok kill stuff within time limit, ok defend this thing now' even in the endgame dungeon Earth Tower   The game is not finished yet, the rumor is that there are going to be 10 ranks of classes with a supposed level cap of 600 (330 and 8 ranks right now) and continued introduction of hidden classes   *Regarding class choices, because of the large variety of classes, there is also a huge chance for making a mistake for your class choices. You cannot undo your class choices without restarting your character. There are a few classes that end up with dead ends such as Corsair 3, without logical and good choice for the next class at rank 8 to take. There are also classes such as Highlander and Featherfoot who have their DPS literally cut in half because some of skills dps only work with certain kind of monsters. There are some straight up broken classes such as Sadhu which can cause a desync bug. Or flat out ineffective classes such as Sadhu again because their main damage skill can be interrupted by a single attack. There are support classes whose function is only to be a repair shop or buff shop. And then there are overpowered classes such as Plague Doctor which has a skill that lets allies ignore rank 2 debuffs. In PvP some class choices completely invalidate others. Such as Plague Doctor's Bloodletting completely shutting down all Wugushi's poisons. Or Sage's Missile Hole blocking all ranged and magic attacks.   The Steam version is the International version containing 2 servers for North America, 1 for South America, 2 for South East Asia, and 1 for Europe. Obviously where the company is based (Korea) they get the latest updates first, Japan second, and International last. The amount of disaprity between our versions is huge. Despite a few months ago a huge update to the system to allow patches from the Korean version of Tree of Savior to come faster to our version, we are still 1-2 months behind. For some reason IMC has been extremely hesitant to port over actual gameplay and content patches to our version, instead favoring cash shop updates and minor UI improvements.   All the fun I had in the game was in experiencing different classes. The first time experiencing some monsters was fun, but after that the game just didn't have any substance other than the class system to me.  And with that I'll leave you a checklist whether or not you should play the game:   Are you okay with artificial difficulty?   Are you able to invest time in the game to earn a premium token through silver if you cannot afford one with money?   Are you willing to reroll a character if you make a fatal class mistake?   Will you be able to stick with your goal despite it being stagnant for months? (PvE, PvP, GvG)   If you play with friends, are they devoted enough to play with you?   If you reach the 'endgame' will you be okay with waiting months before getting actual content updates?  If yes to all, give it a try, and I wish you good luck.

PROS: + Descent Music + Enjoyable Art + Nice In-game community + Constant Events + Multiple Classes with distinct play-styles, I have:   2 Wizards that have enjoyable, yet different styles of play (Lvl 109, LV 81)  1 Archer with a variety of skills that can party or play solo (Lvl 159)  1 Heal-Bot Priest with dreams of being a Monk (Lvl 79)  CONS: - Repetitive, Braindead Events! - Every Patch brings New Bugs and sometimes Old Ones   (Skills stun-lock you for it's duration while not doing its job) - BUGGED QUESTS - BOTS (Been getting better, but still at the point where its still annoying) - Horrific and annoying Language Filter that blocks out 'T!t' in 'Title' and '@ss in 'Pass', but still allows the word '@ss' itself to go through  Literally, of the 336 hours I've spent on this game within 2+ months, leaves me with the feeling that IMC's vision of Tree of Savior is for a quick cash grab and nothing else. Bugs are ignored, major player restrictions are put into place (trading restriction, auction house restriction, party quest restrictions) sometimes with the 'intent' of stumping botting and bot-to-player transactions while collaterally damaging the majority of players' gaming experience.   BUT THANK LORD FOR THE NEW $20 PENGUIN MOUNTS! We have enough resources to pump out selling material, but not enough resources to reduce losing our current players!   But legit, this game is in big trouble right now. Within the 2+ months I've played, the players I've seen in town have drastically reduced and the maps I've explored and re-explored (on new characters) do not have as many people questing or grinding as when I first started. If the top paragraph didn't make it clear, I don't think IMC cares enough about keeping its player base strong and unless they make a drastic change and start clearing up problems that the remaining players are complaining about, this game will die sooner than later.   Like what others have been saying, Until IMC gets their priorities straighter, PEACE!

TL;DR: Tree of Savior isn't for everyone to play with as where it stands, Gameplay wise. Overall its a game with potential to grow but with its current state and management, I wouldn't recommend it.  Hello, Just writing down a review for Tree of Savior.  Let's start off with Graphics and Music/Sound:  Graphics: 7 The game being 2.5D is quite uncommon from most MMO's. Characters models shows decent and distinct design from each class and to each gender. Though at most times you'll be finding yourself to be looking similar to other players for Tree of Savior doesn't go indepth into character customization. Due to the character style and maps, this does give off the 'RO' Nostalgia for most veteran MMO players.  Art for NPC's are good, it gives of a different feeling from just being another 'Anime-esque art'. The environment and Map backgrounds are decent, they give off the right feel for each map for their theme.  Music: 9  BGM, Here is one of the good things from Tree of savior. The BGM for each map are different and gives out off the right vibes depending on the map and its theme. Boss Battle BGM makes you feel that you're fighting something extra ordinary, THOUGH this wil get repititive until later on for each boss fights.  Here but not the least: Gameplay, Community and Management, and oh also Replayability.  Gameplay: 7 The game starts of quite good to decent until you hit poor, rock bottom. Tree of savior revolves MOSTLY around on auto-attacking. From each class, to swordsman, to cleric, to wizard, and archer based classes will be relying on auto attacking whenever their skill rotations are in cooldown or as such until they reach the cherry on getting their supposedly rank 6-7 classes. Skills and Combat gets really stale for a while since Characters to Enemies, from mobs to Bosses will all likely be using/re-using the same skill animation and combat animation.  Progression in the game is very, linear the only spice that adds to it is that some quests are hidden from the quest log, in which A) You either consult a guide online or B) You spend the time exploring and talking to every NPC you'll be seeing in one map. Questing in the game can get REALLY STALE until the higher levels, in which some are riddled with RNG-based item fetching and etc.. Dungeons. The Dungeons in Tree of Savior are either your to go to for EXP at lower until high level grinding but as how it is the the entrance limit for such instances are limited to only 2 runs globally for all dungeons, and 3 runs for token users. Though I do not find any necessity to even limit such runs to a minimum to 2-3 runs daily globally tied to exactly just 2 tickets to use for once a day to a dungeon, which you wont be able to run others after.  Tree of savior possesses a number of different classes branching from their main class from Either, Swordsman, Cleric, Wizard or Archer, with a total of more than 80 classes. Diversity for each class in a game is a plus to me as it divides classes into roles in a party. This is a plus in my book, BUT at most times thanks to the META only a number of class builds and combos are gonna be significant for end game or PVP, in which making a number of class combinations irrelevant. Another thing, Diversity, like I've said just now; Diversity in roles but the issue is that each class branch either feels the same feel in regards to combat or skills, only difference are in terms of bonuses, weaponry used or gimmick.  The game's cash shop is quite empty as many would wonder but most of the part it doesnt have any pay-to-win niche items aside from the enhancement scroll that boosts RNG-based stats on a headgear accessory. Though one more thing, at early levels you might be bothered that some features are locked from the usual free to player, such as trading, storage being shared between your characters, limited amount of items listed on Market(Auction) and having an outstanding 30% tax from selling anything in the market. Not to mention taking money from the auction takes up to 48 hours. Premium, aka Token is the answer to most of these locked features and limited slots but it doesnt reduce amount of days to take out the money from the auction/market but reduces the tax to 10% though! I can't really complain much but this is quite a wall for someone starting from the ground up which maybe inconvenient for the new player in the early levels. The good thing about Token(s) are they aren't exclusive to paying players only. They can be sold in the market by other players, but they cannot be traded amongst token users thru normal trading means. Even though Tokens can be sold in the market/auction, The Price for it stands near the point where you should already even invested where their price stands. Which would take you either to be around getting near Fedimian or already around level100+ to even afford one through silver means. Although Tokens and auction/market are riddled with such walls, they did help combat RMT at some point of level but RMT/Bot users are getting smarter each day and are still eager even with the ban waves from IMC (Good Job IMC for being active in doing so!).   Community: ? In terms of the game community, The game itself has a friendly bunch but at the same time there are hardcore white knights in terms of either light or heavy criticism; Ranging from the Developer's stand point of deciding things and from the game's core gameplay. But overall the game's players are friendly enought or either too quiet enough. Oh for the love of all bad things, the game also has bots around.  Management: 6  IMC has been 'transparent' and been working hard to serve the game to the international audience. But with decisions made in the past in announcing Open Beta to be free from sometime ago into a sudden change of plans into deciding hosting an early access with a price tag of 50$. With such action this suddenly took a great turn into dividing the playerbase, though in light of the majority of the community disliking the early access model. IMC had rather made tiers of purchase for it, In which the community has approved.  One more thing, the fight against RMT and Bots. IMC has stated the reason for having the early access was to combat such illegal activity but the community are divided into either thinking they're just doing this for PR or are actually honest about it. Though no deterrent really last that long if it wasn't really supervised or well made, as bots and RMT were rampant during the early access and with some exploits on the background but IMC has been doing quite well combating them.   Though at the current state of management IMC has really been sloppy with assisting the game's needs and stability. Which I hope be improved upon in the future.  Replayability: Game gets really stale even for a grinding game. It doesn't offer much any feel of accomplishment or triumph. PVP is unbalanced for most of the part and it needs to be polished. PVE aspects as like I said it gets stale as it doesn't offer other gimmicks or necessities besides stated above even with Guilds.  Conclusion, The game may not be for everyone to play on but it does have its own gimmick and perks. It also gives off the same Nostalgia from playing RO from long ago but it just doesn't feel the same way. The state of the game and how it's being handled is quite so-so.  The game right now feels unfinished and still needs tending to. Gameplay and Management-wise, 'Premium' aspect of the game feels like a necessity more than a 'want'. Overall its a game with potential to grow but with its current state and management, I wouldn't recommend it.  Well, That's pretty much it.. Thank you for your patience reading until down here.

'It is a great game with huge potencial.'I said it when it released on Steam more than half year ago, and exact same words I can say it again now. It is a great game with huge potencial, but with this dev team, it will always stay at this state, unfortunately. This game I have 469 hours on my account. I had such high expectation, thought it would be another great game like FFXIV:A Realm Reborn, there's one moment I really thought ToS was my true love in gaming, but it really isn't, it just isn't.

Sadly, I can't recommend this game. I bought into the hype and dropped for the pricy beta package, quickly discovering why that was a bad idea. I mean, the gameplay itself is fun... for a while. The artwork is fine, has that classic Final Fantasy Tactics feel to it, and honestly the storyline isn't bad if you pay attention. But once you get through the quests you can even do, reaching the next ones is a chore and a half. The UI leaves much to be desired. Lot of restrictions on random things. I really, really wanted to like this game, but its charm is ultimately overwhelmed by its flaws.  And from what I'm reading, they're not really doing much in the way of patching lately, and end-game still sounds boring. I also hated how there's no ACTUAL guild system. Can't keep in contact with your friends very well. It's just blah. It had so much potential, but let this one slide, the remorse is real over here.  Edit: I will say one positive thing that hooked me (and hyped me), it plays very well with a 360 controller.

This game is pretty fun. I first read reviews and saw the first 70 or so were all negitive so i decided i was not going to play. Then one of my buddies picked it up and got my curious.  This game is not complete. There are only 7 tiers of job classes taking you to about 225 for the last one. As far as i can tell, they do not plan to stop there and stuff will be added in the future. That being said its very similiar to releasing a beta of the game. That is not as bad as it sounds though. The game is pretty solid with what it does have and gives you a pretty wide range of classes to play. Thousands of different job combos for each of the 4 classes. And different ways to play through the game.   In this game you can grind like a mad man, or you can do daily dungeons and quests and level multiple guys at the same time quite effectively, or you can quest. If you quest, instead of getting the exp reward instantly they give you exp cards. Those cards can be saved up and used to push you through tough levels for you class or however you want. A neat and varried system.  I have a coin, but i can say that i played about a week without one and the difference it makes it pretty insane. Can't really imagine playing without one ever again. The coins unlock many features that are used to limit and frustrate you into supporting the game. I'm not sure if this is the best tactic, but it got me to buy it.   The crafting, item upgrading, gems, cards and pets are all pretty well done. Crafting is actually relevant for obtaining some of the best gears. Upgrading makes almost all peices of gear better in some way. Gems provide neat buffs depending on the peice and can be leveled up to provide bigger buffs. I like these systems.  The worst part about this game is bots and how they are trying to handle them. Atm bots are to a degree ruining certain farmable crafting materials prices by having them constantly farmed. This sucks but it also makes those mats cheaper for those looking to buy instead of farm, but it makes the farming yourself harder. The restrictions on trading and the AH can get pretty frustrating. They were put in to stop bots, but not really working. They are however semi frustrating to real humans. All in all though, they have already patched and made quite a few of them better.... provided you are using a token. The most frustrating part is that you can't move gold between your characters, and if you buy any item off the AH that has no potiential, it becomes bound to that character. These are not that huge as far as negitive impacts go.  I've only had lag for 1 day. It was the day they split servers. Can't really say its an issue at all.   TL:DR Its a solid start to a game with many many fun choices to explore and play out. Bots suck, but aren't that big an issue atm. Alot of the complaints i see are solved by supporting the game and getting an in game Token for premium features. That doesn't mean its pay to win, just lowers frustration level with trade and item limitations. Meaning if you don't have a Token you must be patient.

Pros - Great music - Great art  Cons - Lag - Full of bugs (worse than cbt) - Server crash everyday - Very slow mob spawn rate - Gold spammer (pretty much every MMO have this) - Character slot is shared with pet - Trading is locked behind monthly paywall. Even if you have the Token, you can only trade for 30 times PER MONTH. Even using the Team Storage will use your monthly trade count. The trade count is shared for every character in the team. You can't even trade silver so this restriction just bring stupidity to another level - It took 30 minutes to 2 hours for item to register in the market - It took 48 hours to retrieve the money from selling things in the market - Each materials are limited to 32 per item for the whole (day/week/month not sure about this) and the materials traded will become untradeable. Even Team Storage is limited to this  There's still alot more cons but i guess that is enough, bought the $50 package because the game looks promising but in the end you just sit there waiting for queue and play the game with lag 90% of the time. Pretty much a pay to play open beta. Better wait for the game goes f2p if you want to try the game and do some research about the class (stats and skills) you want to play because any mistakes made are permanent and there will be no free stats or skills reset

Whew where do I begin... To start off I had played Ragnarok Online for a couple of years an had plaed other MMOs as well. So let's start off with the Pros:  1. Good Graphics - artistic and unique 2. Satisfying gameplay - gameplay is really satisfying since most skills will often have a substantial effect on opponents and allies. There are still some skills that need tweaking and bug fixing; however, I woudl say that the game's gameplay is still really solid.   Cons:  1. Grind- I have reached level 190. I can tell you that I have reached several grind walls already but the grind in this game is absurd. What happens if you're 10 levels above or below a monster? 10 levels above a monster = less exp (starting from being 5 levels below or above a monster); however, being 10 levels below will make the monsters hit you harder in addition to having much less exp gain. It's gotten to the point that you really have to read on guides on how to use the exp cards efficiently due to the nature of the grind of this game and how unforgiving it is in terms of gaining experience due to leveling restrictions.   To top it all off, skill resets are only allowed through the use of premium currency, which is extreemely poor taste due to how much grind is involved and how the skill descriptions are really poor.  2. Trade restrictions - My god... I have never seen a game so heavily restrict on it's trading before. You can list only 1 item on the market (non premium user) and you can only trade with other players without the use of the in game currency, which prompts you to barter. Access to the market is only in towns as well. This makes market use cumbersome and often not worth using for the most part, at least from my experience.   3. Pay to win- sever items from the cash shop give combat advantages. Token = movespeed. Enchant scroll = provides you headgear with stat increases. Mind you that these increases are quite substantial, regardless of what people tell you otherwise.   4. Techinical issues- bots, server instabilities, etc. Can be fixed  5. Class Balance and equipment balance - can still be fixed; however, I really will say that the items and class balance are really out of whack right now. As an example for equipment, I am loaded with recipes but I have no materials to craft them even though I keep killing monsters, which often have spawn rates or mob densities that want us wanting more in normal maps. Not that the materials have any value on the market anyway nor can I actually sell them anyway due tot he trade restrictions hahaha.....  Overall, the game is still really rough around the edges and has still to go through a lot to improve. Currently, seeing how this is going to lift it's limited access soon to F2P players, I want to warn prospective players that this is brings in a lot of the archaic and not so good aspect of past MMOs and fails to bring the sandbox feeling of RO in the game with all the restrictions involved.  TL;DR - remove restrictions, improve archaic and obsolete MMO design (e.g. old world boss design, market access, bad spawn rates, etc.), make the grind more bearable, and balance issues in terms of skills and equipment aquisition.

Not gonna say much... What got my interest in this game was the art style and the liberty of the class system. It had potencial. I played for like 8 hours and you might think thats nothing but in so little time I got very disappointed. I agree with the majority of negative things people are saying in the reviews: The interation with other playes is scarce, the class system isnt well developed, its very linear, the story seems really nice at first but it doesnt progress in a interesting way... The game tries to fool you but you can quickly see its flaws. I know this is free to play and all, but Eden Eternal did a much better job with a cute style, a wide class system, etc, wich is a game that I played a lot and loved it. Tree of Savior is disappointing in a way that I don't wanna play any second more. A real shame. =/ (Going back to FFXIV! <3)
Ragnarok Online-tryin-to-be game but far more worse.

I really want to recommend this game (This is supposed to be the actual 'successor' to Ragnarok Online, which I played back in early 2000), but in it's current state, I really can't recommend it.  1. Lag. The lag is awful and I don't think it'll get any better once the game gets out of the 'month early access'. It'll only get worse. Not to mention when I played earlier, channels were crashing, leaving a lot of players to go to 3 channels. I ended up logging out because getting any quests done was next to impossible.  2. F2P players are at a disadvantage. You can't do trades unless you have the 'subscription' aka token active. Like really???? Trading is a basic feature in nearly every mmo! Account wide storage is also behind this wall, which can be a real pain if you're playing more than 2 classes. You get extra speed too, which is useful, but this could be a problem in PvP down the line.  3. Shoutting gold spam. Every night I come on, I have to block the wall of gold spam. It wouldn't be bad if the chat wouldn't lag the game. ~_~ At this point, just turn shouts off.   4. Quests are boring. Very generic quests, but how many ways can you make kill -insert mob here- interesting? Also, make sure you cover every base on a map, quest NPCs are not marked, so you have to watch for a npc anc click on them to see if it's a quest. Can miss out on exp because you're not combing every corner of the map.  5. Research is a must. Before you play, I would highly suggest you goggle the game and see what builds are recommended. Granted, there's a skill/stat reset, but you might save yourself money/time by doing some research yourself.  6. Some bugs. I came across 2 quests I could not complete. Both of them, I could not interact with the object I needed to interact with.  7. Combat is rather boring. As a cleric, I lay down heal, lure monsters in to attack them, and if the monsters are 'floaty', I have to bash it to death with my mace. Rinse and repeat. I'm hoping there's more involved at later levels, but so far, I'm not impressed.  The good about this game? It's a very pretty looking game and the music is there. But as they say, graphics cannot save mediorc gameplay.  Could this be a good game? Yeah, with some polish, it could very well be a good mmo. But in it's current state? I don't see myself playing it long term. I might use as much as I can on the token I used and just move on to something else if nothing comes.

First off I enjoyed the game quite a bit. Great music, great art, fun class system. There is a lot of grinding to the game and to all the people complaining about camped zones, I have a few tips. If you are in a heavy populated channel, change channels and start inviting or requesting invites for a party. When a party member kills, obtains, activates a quest item it gives credit to all nearby party members. I have not had any issue finding the mobs or quest items needed.   The biggest problem and turn off currently is the LAG. If you have to pickup more than 1 quest you have to change channels and wait for load screens or you end up sitting at the quest person for minutes waiting for server to respond with the NPC dialog box. This goes the same with most quests that require you to activate items. The first action on a channel seems lag free and then it goes downhill fast, making constant channel switching the most efficient way to play. This is garbage and servers need to be updated asap. Also because some channels are constantly being restarted by the server causing a disconnect when you join a mew one, you can end up back into a waiting queue if you do channel hop so be careful.  TL:DR - In the current state of things I would not recommend this game due to the shoddy servers. Please save yourself the trouble and do not start playing on F2p release because you will end up frustrated and disgusted quickly by the server states. Wait maybe a month or 2 after release and then give it a go. It is a beautiful game but the lag issues were present in both CB's and its doubtful to be resolved upon f2p release.

The game is not bad, and it has its potential, buts sadly the more you play the more you see that its broken. The nature of that damage could be easily fixed, but despite the tens of thousands of player who have quit because of it (from 50k when it opened to the 4k average of today and still decreasing), its seems developers seem to be focus in leading it to death.   Of the many problems this game has, which the tons of reviews and forum threads make clear, allow me to give 2 very simple examples: Guilds: In my opinion on a MMORPG Guilds are the core of the MMO part. Its the family that you can chose and that makes playing something more enjoyable, they accompany you on it, you talk and play with them, etc. A player with a guild (much more if is a good guild) would have a greater gaming experience and would be much less likely to leave the game.  BUT In this game, guilds are such a high commodity that almost nobody is on one. They are late game content, and extremely restricted to the players, so the great majority of the players can’t access to them. They require dedicate pjs, lots of money and grinding and still only allow few players leaving the baste majority without options.   Partys: Another core element on an MMORPG that its damaged here. While in most games you can have around a 10lv of difference from the 60 to 100 max lvs between the player and mobs, here with 280lvs you can only fight evenly with a 5 high lv difference. If you pass that 5 lv difference penalizations start applying, which increment highly after the 10lv difference and leave mobs with more than 20 lvs almost immune. As you can imagine, with such a low playerbase with decrease each day, on many different servers, distributed over those 280 lvs the chance of finding players which less than 5 or 10 lvs difference its bad, making almost impossible to enjoy most party content.  But the worst part of all that is the ¡¡WHY!! What do the developers have to gain by leaving the players guildless? What do they gain by making partys hard to find? Those two obvious things many have complain about could be fixed in a minute, but after 5 months and tens of thousands of player lost, nothing has been done. Players are still guildless and partys hard to come by with no reason for it at all.

Another game with great art, music and class mechanics ruined by terrible management. The largest problem of the game is trading restrictions: free players can not trade at all and premium players are limited to 30 trades per month, furthermore once an item that isn't equipment is traded, it becomes untradable, which kills the game for merchants. The auction system isn't any better − free players are limited to one auction slot, while premium players have 5, which isn't nearly enough to sustain a healthy economy. Furthermore, there is a 48 hour delay before silver can be withdrawn from the auction house, which makes a lot of players not want to bother with it altogether. The only ones who don't deem to suffer from all of these restrictions are bots and gold sellers, for whom it is a dream come true, considering all the extra clients they're getting because players aren't able to earn silver fairly. IMC has promised to soften the restrictins, yet have done nothing of the sort for two updates. And now to make things worse Steam regional pricing has been removed without warning, making the already expensive premium currency unaffordable for the majority of players. This just continues to show that IMC don't care about their players and are only trying to grab some fast cash.

While we call this game true successor to RO, the graphic style and everything else is but the game play is not. This game is more action oriented with a lot of RPG base element. ( with MMO lagging capability). You can probably grind to LV up but it will be tedious and boring. The fastest way to LV up in this game is to quest.  Let's get to the detail. - Level design is BEAUTIFUL BUT BAD ,especially in the begining where it require players to run around the map to the same place over and over and over again. It get better 90 LV later and might troll us to do it again every few quests. My suggestion is - choose to start from Orsha than Klaipeda - better level design better rewards, less running in circle.  - Class Advancement looks very interesting that we have 50-80 classes to play but it is actually hard, confusing and there is no going back once player choose one( as of this patch). Once you mess up the only correction is to reset and play again.  ... it feel good once you get it right finally...  - Skill cooldown is an ABOMINATION !! TOS will not let you spam skills like in RO instead even less powerful skill will require players to wait for 30 seconds to do 200% damage burst ... did I mention you only have 1-2 attack skills per class advancement?   - Status distribution is BORING !! The game is designed to have max LV around 500. Each status point we distribute early game is very insignificant. it feel really weak to have 50-100 status points in damage stats such as STR or INT a few PVP builds tends to go fully HP oriented since skill damage doesn't scale much with the stats.  - Server lag will be fixed. Once it is this will be one of the game most people can enjoy.  - MUSIC IS GORGEOUS !!!  - GRAPHIC IS BEAUTIFUL !!! AND UNIQUE !!!  - While the game itself is not really optimised ... I play it at 60 FPS the it drop to 15-25 every now and then. Everytime I walk pass people and open a god damn map... or buff people ... or do AOE kills... I kinda don't mind it much. I heard a few people does.   - IMC garunteed there will be 200 bosses to fight over ... they are all camped by high LV people and monopolised the market.  - You cannot trade money - I think they try to stop Chinese gold scammer but they still use Marketplace to do it. In the end this affect the in-game economy a lot.   - Trading only allow for VIP people, still no money trading... even VIP have limited number of times they can trade. So I don't trade... much.  - TREE OF BUGs !!! bugs are every where. Seems like this tree attract more bugs than Bugframe or Bugscroll online.  - Game designer decide to help solo player ... with x6 experience with dungeon finder but give no bonus to normal party ... talk about double standards.  - Why am I still recommending this.... I'm drunk I guess. forget it play the game. see for yourself.

Now that free to play is out i will update my review.  The good  -Music is amazing -Even without min maxing most classes are useful in some way -Classes are usually fun to play. -I enjoy the art style  The bad  -Tooltips for some skills are still missing information or not showing cooldown timers. -Some skills are broken -Terrible pet AI for the classes that use them -Poor leveling experiance through certain level ranges, This can be mitigated and avoided with planning but new players coming in blind will get stuck in the 160ish-186 zone with a terrible grind. -No UI resize controls or way to move UI features. -Need an addon to show exact experiance gain -Dungeon runs are capped at 3 runs per day, In the beta it was 5 per dungeon per day idk why they changed it -No trading money between alts, Money is tied to the character that gets it making crafting classes less useful for players -Cant directly trade boss cards which 3 different classes use for skills Wugushi, Necromancer, and Sorcerer -Bots so many bots and no real system to remove bots in place. You can report them but its not really helping the situation. They do ban bots but what they are doing does not seem to affect the rate of bots at all especially on the weekends when all the gms take a break. -The game is terribly optimized and it shows, massive slowdowns and lagfests during world boss fights even on powerful computers -For a grinding game the spawn rate is terrible expect 5+ minute wait times to kill things on many high level maps especially if you are not alone on the map. The spawn rate is still terrible in ftp they completely ignored this issue outside of one patch note early that had no real effect on the mob respawn problems.   IMC did not fix much of anything from the early access to the free to play release. This game has so much potential but it feels like IMC is trying kill it with poor support. If IMC can get their act together this game will be great but so far i dont have much hope for it.

I liked the charming look of ToS, the stat & skill customization, and the variety of classes... but that wasn't enough to keep me or friends I came with interested in the game. I was the last of my group to quit because I was stubborn and wanted to keep giving this game a chance, but the game just wasn't getting better.  -CONS-  *IMC (the company that developed the game)*  -Don't communicate with their playerbase enough  -Nothing gets done in a timely manner  -They put stupid restrictions on everything  -They let game breaking bugs continue to plague ToS to this very day  -Forums have no moderators  -Forums have no community manager to talk with the playerbase  -There are gamebreaking bugs that have been in the game since the beginning with no acknowledgement from IMC   *Game bugs*  -People in a party get stuck (can't move or use skills) whenever someone in the same party starts a cut scene  -The goddess saule quest still is buggy for characters that started the quest when the game first came out  -Disconnections while trying to switch characters  -People are exploiting game breaking bugs  -Unbreakable weapon upgrades bug  -Infinite party members bug  -Druid class transformation crashing game channels  The game breaking bugs that I just listed have been first talked about on 7/18 and now it's 7/21 with no fix and people are still crashing channels and freely upgrading weapons without having to lose potential on the weapon. IMC made a short message on their site on 7/19 about it. They haven't done any thing in the game to fix any of it and they've made no post on the forums. People have suggested temporary fixes like temporarily making the druids unable to use the transform skill til they can come up with a more permanent solution, but IMC won't do any thing about it.  *PvP in the game is lackluster*  -The only PvP are duels and consensual GvG  -There's no reward for doing GvG  -There's no battlegrounds/arenas  *Guilds*  -The guild leader MUST be a templar to make a guild  -Guild can only hold up to 35 people when level'd  -Guild list doesn't show what class the people currently are  -Guild missions don't work most of the time  -Nothing in the game makes guilds unique from eachother (no guild buffs, castles, etc... like you find in other games)  *Leveling*  -Quests dry up when you get to 230+  -You MUST grind monsters for hours in a party to get your last levels.  *End-game*  -The only thing you'll find yourself doing once you reach 280 is the only end-game instance called Earth Tower, grinding mobs or world bosses for money, or making a new character.  *Bots and gold sellers*  -I've come across bots on every map and channel in the game  -The gold sellers are annoying spamming in the cities with their huge chat bubbles that get in the way  *Character look customization*  -Can only choose from a small list of hairstyles and can't even choose the hair color when making a character  -Can only choose black, pink, blonde, blue, or white hair later in-game through achievements  -Can only choose different hair styles by paying for it in their cash shop  -PROS-  *Character stat and skill customization*  -Can freely choose what stats and skills you want your character to have  *Classes*  -Variety of classes that you can put together on one character  *Music*  *Art style*   The pro's couldn't keep me and others I know playing the game. Just way too many bugs, lack of care from IMC, boring PvP, and boring end-game.

Something about this game just feels.. lacking. It's not bad per se, but this is probably the fastest I got burned out from playing an MMO. What.. around 1 week?  It's marketed as a spiritual successor to Ragnarok Online, but I really don't feel the resemblance besides being 2.5D and having somewhat similar art.  From a technical standpoint, the game is somewhat poorly optimized and starts lagging considerably at around 10+ players on-screen, dropping to a janky 40 fps for a medium setup like mine. For reference, I can run something like The Witcher 3 on max settings at around the same framerate. For a 2.5D game, this is very concerning.  Gameplay-wise, I don't think it even captures the charm that RO had in its time. The overworld there was huge and exploration was fun... plenty of towns and dungeons to explore in no particular order. Here you've got like 2 towns and levelling is as linear as it gets. Go to this map.. level up a bit and do some quests.. now go to this conveniently adjacent map.. level up some more.. rinse and repeat. As for the quests, whereas RO's quests were hidden and scattered like easter eggs with interesting rewards, the quests here are a dime a dozen and either just kill, fetch, or click quests for some amount of XP and disposable gear.  I won't even get into the player trading, auction house, and botting.. a lot of people already have those covered.   Who knows.. maybe it all gets better in the late game. Regardless, the journey to get there sure is boring as hell though.

After leveling a character to 150, I feel this game is in noway ready for release. It is littered with bugs, server lag, poor design choices and a lack of variety and content past level 120ish.   Pros: +fantastic art style - this looks very unique compared to it's modern counterparts while at the same time feels familiar to anyone who has played ragnarok online +satisfying combat - combat feels fast and fluid and attacks have a very satisfying feel upon use  Cons: -Server lag/crashes - when you are limited to 2 dungeon runs a day and the exp gained contributes a signficiant part to leveling, it is stupid for the instance to crash and boot you out while consuming a daily dungeon run -Horrible way to counter gold sellers/botters - gold sellers and botters are still rampant and doing a google search on gold sellers, it is easy to tell that all the measures this game has in place hasn't worked. On the down side, it is terrible for actual players. Non paying customers can only trade playing customers but any traded item becomes character bound (destroys resale value once you outlevel your gear). You can't trade money to anyone - friends included. Auction House allows only 1 item listing for non playing customers with a 30% AH fee (10 items with 10% ah fee for paying customers). You can only collect money from the AH after 48 hours. -Lack of content for progression past level 120 - unless you count endlessly grinding mobs for 0.01% or doing daily dungeons as content. Current max level is 250 - 300 so there is a huge grind wall ahead... -Dungeons become painfully long and repetative - dungeon design is uninspiring and only worth doing a handful of times but most people go for full clears not because it is fun but because of the vital exp needed to continue the grind -Though it is free to play the game is severely gimped without a subscription. It becomes impossible to meaningful play the AH without a subscription. For a grinder, efficiently killing things is ontop of the list of priorities but withouyt a sub your character moves significantly slower and receive 30% less exp  -Character stats cannot be reset as of today and while skill points can be reset - job changes are fixed. As such, without a lot of prior research, there is a very likely chance that you will need to reroll if you want to play something that is decent.  Overall, this game starts off being alot of fun with it's nice visuals and initially fun combat but soon devolves into your standard korean grinder. Implementation feels old and dated (something from 10 years back) and the sad thing is...there was no reason to make it as bad as this. Taking queues from say GW2 - you don't have to gimp non premium player progression - just add alot of visually pleasing cosmetic goods in the cash shop. IMC didn't need to lock down trade features so heavily to try and prevent botters. Worst of all, there was no reason to make the grind wall as severe as it is...The game has an enormous set of classes and builds to try, I would much rather play a variety of different classes and builds rather then grind a single character ad infinitum.

TREE OF HORROR  Pros: + Beautiful art + Diverse class system + No grinding needed until very late in the game  Cons: + Infested with bots and gold sellers in town. I feel the urge to quit this game everytime I walk to town. Gold sellers spam in every channel to the point you literally can not chat in town without going to a very far corner. And the devs do nothing about this, they could have a mute function, chat cooldown, GM monitoring,etc but no, they're too busy thinking of new way to restict legit players  + As I said, they punish regular players, not bot. They're trying to reduce human interaction to the minimum. Everything is restricted, no trade between players, only 1 item on market without token, 48 hours wait before you can get the money from the items you sold, team storage requires token, etc. You're no different from a bot playing this game, grind, do quest, upgrade equipments, repeat. No human interaction needed except for partying.  + LAG! LAG! LAG! Even in the least populated channel the delay is horrible. Your character attack twice on screen and only one damage tick appears. And don't even bother with charging skills. Fully charged skill with minimal damage is the norm in this game.  + Stupid AI and ridiculously short buff duration. I get that they want to prevent bot from afk farming, but dumping down the game just for that is ridiculous. Your pet, your summoned, your converted mobs, etc are stupid as hell. They do nothing and have no damage. The only thing they do is making your lag worse. Buff duration is too short to make support classes worth while, most of the time the priests don't even bother buffing you because it's such a hassle to rebuff every minute. And did I tell you that the buff aoe is so small that you'll miss most of the time?  + A lot of game mechanics are not explained in the game. You have to read on the forums for that.  + The game is no where near polished enough for open beta. This is more like early access. You literally have a dozen quests with descriptions like this 'Kill %s', 'Find %s', 'Get %s'. And it is near unplayable without a ♥♥♥♥ ton of fanmade addons because the game UI design is ♥♥♥♥ing terrible.  In conclusion, don't play this game unless you have a lot of time to waste, because that's essentially all you'll do in this game.

Summary  TOS is a beautiful 2.5D game with amazing artistic designs. Customization creates depth in the game-play. However, players interaction could be further encouraged. Game play needs to be more balanced. More varieties need to be implemented. Given the momentum of the developers, the game has a lot of potentials to be greater.  Pros  This game is an eye candy. The maps and character designs are amazing. It truly stepped up its game in the artistic department comparing to Ragnarok, which was a beautiful game to begin with. The map has different layers of backgrounds creating such depth. You may be crossing a bridge high up in the mountain while finding other players fighting monsters deep in a small valley underneath. A 2.5 D game with such style puts even many 3D MMORPG in shame.   The game offers an enjoyable RPG experience. It allows so much customization. The number of classes and skills in each allows two late game characters of the same class to have completely different play styles. The drop rate is decent. Gears are easy to get. I never find myself short of resource to buy merchandises. Free users are at little disadvantage comparing to the paying ones.  The devs are still actively fixing the game's issues. The lagging issue which was causing huge uproar was fixed in a week. The trade system has been brought back. The developers listen to what their customers want and they make it happen. This game is being constantly improved. Hopefully the user experience would be even better in the future.  Cons  The game struggles to create a cohesive experience as a MMORPG. It does not encourage players to cooperate. For example, doing quests alone is far more rewarding than anything else due to the low difficulty of the game. This results in every player focusing on playing alone rather than being part of the greater world. Remember the merchants on the streets of the major cities in Ragnarok making the world so lively? The market place is a cheap replacement to that formal glory. Even though there are plenty players, it lacks a spirit of a living world.   The classes are not balanced. Despite allowing customization, certain build provides far better leveling experience comparing to another. It requires user to do their homework before actually playing the game. Some skills are traps by being completely under-powered. It is not that kind of game which rewards you for being devoted to a certain path. Hence stepping on to the wrong path means either starting over or buying $ item to reset the character.  Lastly, behind its pretty face, the game gets repetitive really fast. All minions on every level feels the same from lv1 to lv50. It is great to fight a boss every now and then, but it feels like the same boss with different skins/animations except a few. Quest comes in different formats, but all too trivial. They should be more distinctive and memorable. However, the hidden ones are really pleasant surprises. I remember finding a red gem which took me to a boss battle against a monster guarding it. Make these more common! Overall, the grinding experience feels a bit bland.  Conclusion  It has been fun, but I am stopping playing this game because the cons outweigh the pros. I will not enjoy the same experience for another 35 hours. The game is still worth a try for new comers.

(For people who just want a quick summary, pros and cons are listed below. )  Do you love the original Ragnarok Online? Was Ragnarok 2 a bitter dissapointment? If yes....you can download this in a hardbeat because this is pretty much it's spiritual successor. This game was conceived by Ragnarok's original project lead Kim Hakkyu who founded IMC Games when he left Gravity game studios. This game just has the original Ragnarok vibe all over.   If no this game is still pretty compelling. You see I love MMO's but I'm not that fond of endgame. What makes this game pretty unique is it's class system. You start with one of the four base classes Archer, Cleric, Swordsman or Wizzard. Your max class level is 15 and every time you hit this you can either take a second or third rank in your current class or you can take a different class. New classes get added each time you hit class level 15. This makes your character very custimizable to your own taste. Currently there are 7 total class rank (including your base class) but more will be added in the future.  Tho not all class combinations are optimal all of them are pretty much viable. I personally think the class system adds a lot of fun to the game.   Honestly I did expect a lot of grinding from a Korean MMO but it does not become grindy until level 130-140 ish. Up until then there is a lot of content to go through. There is a sort of subscription you can either buy with real money or either with ingame currency which gives extra benefits. But nothing game breaking, of the group of friends the person with the highest level was the one that did not have premium even tho premium gets you +30% mob experience.   Yes going full free to play has it's limitations but nothing mayor....some of the limitations are imposed to make the job of Gold Sellers more difficult. Tho I think it's a nice try it does not currenly have the desired effect.   All in all I can give this game a recommendation, especially when the games free to play launces. I will list some of the pro's and cons below. Just give it a go once the free to play launches because well...it's free. This will definitely be one of the better free to play MMO's. It has been able to keep my attention more then any other MMO is recent years and I've tried many.  I don't get a lot of the hate this game is getting, frankly it's a lot of crying about nothing.  Pros -Undeniable and unique charm -Some fantasic music scores -Downtime gets you free cash shop items as compensation -Premium can be bought with ingame cash -Collections, map completion, mission dungeons give you a lot to do.  -Lots of content -Lively community -More content and less restrictive then most asian free to play MMO's  -Players get rewarded for playing with others  Cons -Other music scores can be throwaway and lackluster -Some of the measures against gold sellers do not hit their mark -PVP is lackluster and needs a lot of work -Party Search for dungeons needs work -Gold seller bots are still a problem (tho they are currenly working to resolve this) -Say goodbye to your social life

IMC went to ridiculous extents to protect their profits and gave this game one of the most restrictive and punishing experiences for Free to Play players that I've ever seen since Guild Wars 2 with the upcoming of Heart of Thorns expansion.  P2P interaction is EXTREMELY RESTRICTED to the point that no Silver (ingame currency) and / or items can be traded between players, and can only have 1 item on Auction House, which will by the way take a cut of the 30% of the item value.  This, however, does not apply to paying users who purchase tokens (which can be bought with ingame currency if you can find one at an actualy affordable price and are willing to churn up the price every 30 days...) who get more of practicaly everything and can actualy interact with other players besides grinding and joining parties.  And as a topping for the cake, they delayed the release of the game until 10th May so they can milk up more cash with the Early Access packs that they so eagerly put as soon as they could... not before eliminating the lowest tier pack (which was 9,99€) and setting a new lowest price at 14,99: 50% of the former price.  This game may have people who made RO in their ranks, but as of now, they are nowhere close to be considered even related to Ragnarok Online.  So far, a dissapointment after another is the tune of this game's 'release'.

Despite that, I've had a very positive and enjoyable experience so far and I don't see that changing anytime soon.  The devs are also constantly taking the voice of the community into account when releasing their frequent updates. The most recent update will alleviate the complaints on trading and team storage restrictions that you've all read about. If they continue on this path (I've witnessed no signs at all that says otherwise) then ToS will only get better and better.  Pros:  -Gorgeous art. Very unique in a saturated genre. -Fluid combat system that works great with a gamepad. -Tons of class choices (around 80) and even more are planned. -Stat points to customize your unique (or cookie cutter) build to your liking, leading to many different play styles. -Pleasant soundtrack. -Dev team that is adamant on fighting bots and gold sellers. -In-game bot reporting system complete with rewards and punishment for abusing the tool. -Cash shop pay to win aspect is extremely minor so far. Mostly cosmetics. -Good amount of crafting available. -F2P. Premium token can be acquired with in-game currency, which has been fairly easy to accomplish thus far if you know what you're doing (a few days grinding for your average low to mid level players, even less if you're higher level or skilled).  Cons:  -Needs optimization. Very sluggish in crowded areas, especially main cities even though you may have a boss PC. -Very linear quest system. Only a problem when you decide to make a few characters. -Price of premium (~$18 USD) is very expensive even when compared to AAA titles and their subscriptions. -Some premium token features (team storage, less restricted trading) are available as standard in most other games. -The sheer amount of classes can be punishing if you take a misstep somewhere along the line so plan wisely. -Low spawn rates (although this is always subject to change). -Huge item market selling tax without premium token (30% vs 10%). -48 hours to retrieve silver after selling item in market (to fight gold sellers).

Given that I speak from experience ranging from iCBT2 and, as of this time of writing, the early access my views of this game is pretty limited. But here goes:  The game is, despite the staggering amount of people throwing down 10 dollary-doos or more, a work in progress. We got in early to both actually play the game and to see if IMC can handle the numbers we're currently throwing at thim. Needless to say, its been...rocky. CommanderLoadFail and his gang have not been kind to us but given past experiences, what MMO has had a flawless launch? Not too many.  Still with little than less of a month left to go IMC has been dealing with the rampant issue of RMTs, Bots, and possibly the developer's curse of fixing 1 bug and spawning 99 others in its place. As a player I'm generally patient, I don't entirely understand or pretend to know the inner workings of a company when it comes to managing an MMO, so I put my hopes in the team to know what they're doing and not entitle myself to anything. I don't particularly hold this game up to other standards as, again, experience has shown me that I can't expect Game Y to be like Game X, otherwise why not play Game X.  Give this a shot if you have money to spare, if you don't then feel free to wait until Free to Play to give it a dip, Tree of Savior's experience is reminiscent of Ragnarok Online and hitherto vastly different from the MMOs in the current market. Which may in fact be one of the factors that drew so many into this game.  Just keep in mind that it's early access, it basically means an open beta so you're bound to see bugs galore and run into trouble every once in a while.

It's a decent game to turn your brain off to.  It seems like your typical grinding F2P MMO but somewhere along the way the rollercoaster derails. The quests will outlevel you or glitch and tou're forced to stay in particular zones grinding out mobs for 10-20 levels, some of which are being 'camped' by 5 person parties. It's easy to get invited to one of these parties but it gets very boring to grind. I can spend hours grinding with no objective and level up several times, and this is just 30-40... there are hundreds of levels. Not to mention leveling up your job as well which is a 15 level grind that is objectively slower than leveling regularly. Once you reach level 50 you can begin doing dungeons, I haven't actually made it to 50 yet. I made it to 40 just doing quests and grinding out level 30-40. If you have that kind of patience, to each his own but I need some faster gratification!  The game really suffers from FPS problems, the fps meter they conveniently place on the screen shows 60-100fps then quickly dips to 6fps when the screen gets busy. This really sucks because you're consistently grinding, and if you're smart you're in a party which makes the screen busier. The game is very demanding apparantly and I don't think it has much to show for it. I really support the idea behind this game but I thought the execution really needs some work. It's hard to be immersed in your character and creating an alt because that's a million more hours grinding which actually feels hindering.

Edited on 11/27/16 after break and 1 month return :  This game is still great. I wish that this game continues to grow and thrive, and that more people will come to know it. This is a wonderfully unique game with so much class customization, unique gameplay between classes and sub-classes, as well as a living player run economy of all kinds of crafted weapons, recipes, items, armor sets, monster cards, gems, hats, and more!   I am on Klaipeda (NA) and though the population has declined since launch, as all MMO's do, there are still plenty of people in town and you bump into people while out leveling all the time. Some sub-classes are able to sell class specific buffs that normally other people couldn't use, but you get to rent them for coin. Others repair your armor and weapons over the typically limit so you have to take less trips to town, and there are others as well who provide services to other players when they aren't out adventuring.   There are just too many things that are great about this game. I wish that you would give it a chance and learn to love it like I do. Whether you want to have a few minutes soloing and grinding for 'zen' feelings, or you want to get into a group to farm experience or items or run dungeons this game can accomodate many different feelings.   If you need friends or are looking for a guild, please check out the  Treeofsavior.com  forums as well as Tree of Savior Fanbase which is also a great website for mapping out your Class builds and all your skill points. There is also an item search database on that website for when you are having trouble finding something or someone.   This game has been touted as the 'spiritual succesor of Ragnarok Online' and it holds true to that, but It's also so much more including much more varied class choice, customization and an incredibly more fluid movement and combat system.   Good luck, and may the Goddess watch over you!  Eldaran - Klaipeda Server (NA)

I wanted to like this game, but the experience was extremely frustrating.  First, the good:  1. The cash shop is no big deal. Mostly cosmetic and convenience items. The EXP bonuses for cash are small, only 30%. They don't create an immense divide based on shelling out loads of cash. Leveling doesn't take terribly long. The onyl thing worrying is the item that allows you to instantly revive where you died.  2. There's a large variety of classes, so you can play how you want to play. If you can't find a group, you can easily solo.  3. Cutesy anime art-style, if you like that kind of thing.  4. Getting round the map is convenient with warp scrolls and warp points, so you won't spend all day running all over the place.  Now .. the bad.  1. This game takes the primary purpose of an MMO -- having lots of other people to play with, and basically flushes it down the toilet. It takes far too long to be able to find and join a guild. Unless you're level 100, you are wasting your time even trying to find one, because of the pointless requirements to create one -- only ONE character class is allowed to create guilds, and that character has to be level 224. Why would you ever do that? It boggles the mind. Guilds are limited to 20 players initially, and can be expanded to a max of 35, further worsening those artificial restrictions. It will take you about 50-75 hours of play time to reach level 100 on your first character, BTW. So you basically won't have a guild to join until you've played the game for at least 50 hours.  2. All social aspects of this game are grossly lacking. Finding people to play with in the game is a pointless exercise in frustration. There's no system to look for groups except when queueing for a dungeon, and you have to stand still at the dungeon entrance while waiting in the queue. There is no region chat or way to create custom chat channels for people to join, like an LFG channel. The only way you can reach a large audience is by purchasing a 'megaphone' for real cash and sending a server-wide message that scrolls across the top of everyone's screen with it. A large chunk of players in the maps I was doing quests on were bots, anyway. All emphasis on being social and playing with other people is void. There is none of it. This is a solo-MMO game. Why would you play an MMO if you want to solo everything?  3. Buffs, buffs, buffs. This is another MMO that requires you to constantly manage copious amounts of short term buffs in order to be effective. You have to spam your buffs on yourself every 30-60 seconds, and you need to frequently return to town to get buffs from player character vendors to be able to beat enemies in a reasonable time frame.  4. The battle is rather simplistic, with really long cooldowns on your good abilities that you need to use to defeat monsters in a reasonable time frame. I was playing as a Hoplite, and I had to run around, gathering big groups and smash them with a skill on a nearly 30 second cool down. It made combat feel very slow.  6. Melee classes, once again, in yet another MMO, are mediocre at best. This is a constant issue in MMOs, and almost every new MMO that comes out suffers from this problem at launch.   7. Gold spammers. Bots. They've had an embargo on players for creating a new account for almost a MONTH and there's still tons of bots and gold spammers. Cripes.  So, overall, lotsof potential - but it falls extremely flat on its face due to truly confounding choices by the developers. I REALLY wanted to like this game, but the issues are just too glaring for me to stick it out any longer.

Support is non-existant, optimisation is 0, the only good part about this game is its concept.

I wanted to love this game but...  I'll start with some developmental flaws: the performance is unreliable/buggy even on an overpowered PC - it is not optimized. Lots of 'rubber banding', frame rate drops and mysterious lag as well. The controls are shoddy, especially when trying to execute a directional move. This game has been in development for over a year now, there is little reason it should not at least be optimized. That being said, most of the flaws I will further point out are not developmental ones, but design flaws.  The economy. There are instrinsic mechanics set in place to devalue items, thus eventually rendering them useless. Trading between players requires a token. Tokens are purchased with real cash. This can be circumvented by buying one off the market, but the economy makes this difficult since prices keep climbing as silver-farming zones become more congested. You are restricted to selling one item at a time, unless you have a token. I would describe the real money transaction system is 'pay to make it bearable'.  Swarming with bots: This contributes to the poor economic conditions of the game, and high prices on the market attract a lot of RMT activity. This cyclical problem is represented well here. These bots will also be competing with you for farming items and money as they are seemingly an integral and permanent obstacle of the game.  There is a VERY restrictive cap on the amount of dungeons you can run for loot and experience. 3 mission dungeons + 3 loot dungeons (if you purchase a token, otherwise this total is 4) per day leaves you with little to do aside from grinding. There is not much raiding going on here.   The community. The game does not incentivize teamwork. Most things can be done solo, aside from running a few instances a day with strangers. The field bosses are on static timers, and thus are 'poop-socked' by the grand-fathered few. The lack of a socially dependent community results in lots of name calling, greifing, and general unhelpfulness. Asking questions will typically incite a response with the maturity level of a 'Your Mom' type insult or a snarky antisocial retort. New players are looked down upon - This is just the norm here. Perhaps all the flaws in the game leave the community feeling bereft, and they take their toxicity out on one another.   I put over 200 hours into this game, as well as founding donation cash, believing that it would improve, but it seems that the aforementioned issues continue to spiral downward and compound one another. I really wanted this game to succeed. In my experiences as an MMO player, poor communities and economies stem from bad game mechanics, pay-walls, unchecked exploitation and a pure lack of moderation. This game is a hot, steaming pile of everything that can possibly go wrong in an MMO and a sad dissapointment. Aspiring game developers should use this as a template of what not to do.  It is easy to fall into a habit of complacency when tolerating a game's broken issues in the hopes that things will progress. However, do not fall into this phsychological pattern and squander your finite time on this planet over this game. It is just not worth it. There are many great, finished products out there that can offer what this game falls short on.  My advice: find a stable, subscription based MMO with a helpful community and active GMs.

I had high expectations for this, even tho i didnt want to buy early access i was pretty hyped. Now i am happy i didnt. Game has a lot of flaws, most major atm are server issues, euro server is not even that populated and it constantly lags, i am playing archer and i do double dps when it doesnt lag.  ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ auction system - you cant buy/sell anything for 72 hours when you start to play, when you finally can start selling tooltips on items you put on auction(average price and stuff) are completely wrong, you need to check every material(and after 72 hours i had about ~90 of them) manually. But that isnt everything, even if you manage to sell something you need to wait 48 hours to get your silver. This makes absolutely no sense to me. Other major issue is forced party play. Being in a group gives you more xp then solo. In full group you can get 450% more xp per monster, considering half of the areas are dead/close to dead this makes no sense again. Why should solo gameplay be punished in a grinding game, i have no idea. Next issue is dungeon queue. Considering you get even more bonus xp(600%) if you dont make premade group for dungeon, you need to queue for some to get good xp. Well, 99% of the time you just gonna stare at 'Searching for party' window for hours if you have nothing else to do. Also game has no info on dungeon locations, but that is tolerable considering queue mechanic itself. Queue should be long distance and not require you to wait at dungeon entrance, period. Oh and 1 more thing about dungeons, 90% of the time you get nothing, there are total 2(+1 when you get premium token) entrances COMBINED per day. Actually its not that bad since you cant even find group for 1 dungeon, lol.  Now about good stuff, art/locations/quests are actually pretty enjoyable, characters are really cute.  But considering party play will probably stay same and I am really not a fan of grinding normal monsters with other people, i have doubts i am gonna enjoy playing this game further.

I joined this game the day it opened, well hyped thanks to Ragnarok nostalgia and everything I had seen from BETA. Four years of watching tid bits of information leaking out just to jump on board! It is very buggy, unoptimized to the point literally the only way to fix the game would be to rework it from the ground up, has the absolute worst customer service I have ever seen, next to no communication or even moderation with the player base, monotanous daily dungeons/almost mandatory quest system, and recently went the gacha pay-to-win-so-you-can-skip-grind route... It's just terrible.   I have never played a game and regretted spending money on it. I also have never quit a game and gave away all of my character's stuff to a good friend so I at least know someone is enjoying the grind I put in.   Do not recommend unless you're a masochist and a whale simultaneously.

This game is a lot of fun. Most of the other people already posted the PRO and CONS, so I'll just give my opinion. Yes, it has a few problems. Lag issue was mostly solved for me, so far I'm not having any issues. Gold Sellers stopped spamming shout since they tweaked a few things. One thing you need to understand is that we can't trade silver in game, so there's no silver selling. Gold sellers are there for scams. Bots can be a problem, but they'll have to be very creative to bypass the restrictions and ruin the economy (Edit: I can see now that this was very optimistic of me. They'll still need to hunt bots aggressively, and I hope they do.)  Looking at the market restrictions I understand why they did it. If you played Ragnarok Online (and albeit a different game, ToS is similar in many aspects) you'd know that game was infested with bots. They grew so large the staff couldn't contain them. They ruined every aspect of the economy, so much you thought 'since everyone is doing it, I might as well do it.' The trading and market system in ToS probably has that in mind, and that's why, even though I won't say it's a good thing, it is a design choice that could end up working with some effort. As for tokens, they're as low as 350k right now, maybe they'll drop even more. I hope they will allow some simple form of trading, but I can say that not playing this game only because of that would be your loss.  Tl;DR: Game is a lot of fun, the most fun I had in years in a MMO. And I played most of them. It has flaws, it has grind, but so far it has been worth it. Just play and enjoy. If you're waiting for f2p, that's okay, there'll probably be issues again but you will still have a good time.
